Hornby Station, on the Midland Railway line from Hellifield to Lancaster Green Ayre, opened in 1849. Following closure of the line the track was removed in 1967. The station was located on the Farleton border. https://t.co/zleusPqlRs
The Edwardian decade in Lancaster was one of expansion, modernisation and innovation. The railway from Green Ayre to Morecambe and the Port of Heysham, via Castle Station, was electrified in 1908 to test this new technology and fully operational by 1909  https://t.co/112HvlEnjS
The Observatory, Williamson Park, Lancaster. The observatory, now demolished, was built by the Corporation of Lancaster to house astronomical instruments presented by the then owner Albert Greg Esq., J.P. of Escowbeck, Caton and opened on 29th July 1892. https://t.co/DAeO48wsoe https://t.co/whVxdCkhIF

Bank Holiday Weekend Walk - this weekend we publish guide number 125 to the Lancaster & Morecambe District by their author Gordon Clark. These guides are an unbelievable facility highlighting and promoting what a fantastic area that we live in is.  https://t.co/R0BjKG7oNv
Appearing in 1994 were the Chessmen featuring Paul ‘Woodie’ Woodruff (later to become a councillor and popular face behind the cafe counter at Crook o’ Lune)  https://t.co/BD1XWaaDE9
Market Square 4 - Market Square 9th August 1902, Coronation Day showing the Ox Roasting. The police in attendance are wearing Army surplus helmets left over from the Boer War. Sergeant Johnson is standing at the entrance to Chancery Lane https://t.co/EIwjh61JSL
Take this survey regarding the future, or lack of it,  of parking in Lancaster. Lancaster is the only 'tourist' city that actively discourage 'tourists'. We need to bring tourists to our city to enjoy our amenities and facilities,  not 'drive' them away https://t.co/AcpNoqSfxL
Middleton Community Woodland and Wildlife Reserve is now a wetland area of ponds and reedbeds, home to great crested newts and dragonflies as well as wintering wading birds.  https://t.co/pqv2bg03bO
Hanging Corner, Lancaster Castle. Framed in the doorway of the pinioning room is the chair made in 1828 for Jane Scott. She was too weak to walk, and it was used to convey her to the public gallows which were erected facing the churchyard. https://t.co/O3YRVsAj1h
There are many lovely walks along the River Lune through Lancaster. The riverside paths are all nearly level and paved except for a short section approaching the Lune Aqueduct from the north bank.  https://t.co/ly2hvfdo3K
The LMS railway company commissioned Oliver Hill to design a new hotel in the then fashionable ‘moderne’ style that we would now call Art Deco. Morecambe had seen nothing like this.  https://t.co/r7nIbnz5Xr
The site of Scotforth Pottery, Lancaster which was absorbed into the Hala Road housing scheme. The Stream - Scotforth or Borough Beck - is for some of its length in a culvert. In the field to the right could be seen the clay pits. https://t.co/IHGrwYRUQZ
Since at least October 2022 the windows of this historic building have been missing and the building is in a dangerous situation that requires urgent action https://t.co/gukxWuB4Vk
Can anyone identify any of these young ladies?  Morecambe and Heysham athletic display team 1930s - photo Lancaster and District in old photographs by Susan Ashworth & Nigel Dalziel https://t.co/jGlC5WPVef
The second Lancaster Dispensary on Castle Hill. The recess for the plaque of the Good Samaritan is over the doorway and above the plaque the word 'DISPENSARY' can be seen very faintly https://t.co/TmpDIskRQ8
As Northern Rail are constantly cancelling services on this line at a minutes notice due to staff shortages - they must have loads of job vacancies for anyone looking for one - it might be best to drive to these walks to guarantee not having to walk home https://t.co/KkX01Gxhbc
Famous Morecambe 'Warblers' include Dame Thora Hird, Thora’s daughter Janette Scott, ballerina Fiona Chadwick and, a regular now on the West End stage, Mark Isherwood.  https://t.co/HH7LK1C7W0
The beauty competitions at the baths, and nettle beer at Heysham, and the shows at the park … horse riding on the beach and a swimming pool that was refreshed at high tide. My – 60 odd years later and it is all flooding back – what memories!  https://t.co/pwQwhTaChq
The Landing Sheds, St George's Quay, Lancaster. Removed in 1901-02 when the Port Commissioners gave the Quay to the Corporation. https://t.co/xWYaMX8DE7
A Labour Party Conference has been held in Morecambe once only - 1952. Michael Foot, a future leader of the party, described it as ‘rowdy, convulsive, vulgar, splenetic, threatening at moments to collapse into an irretrievable brawl’.   https://t.co/qjZ8TDiulZ
Morecambe's Heritage Centre describes the area as eclectic, idiosyncratic, individual, quirky, spirited, soulful, legendary, timeless, unorthodox, maverick, unpredictable and tranquil. Easier to go and visit than look those words up in a dictionary!  https://t.co/sCtlIgGCyr
The Great Hall at Lancaster University was a 'Rockin' great place' to be last Saturday night to celebrate being 'the' venue for music in the North-West between 1969 and 1985. Civic Vision's heritage plaque was unveiled commemorating this historic event.   https://t.co/j1M2Q6394C
Wealthy merchants formed the Lancaster Port Commission and the building of the Quay was completed in the 1750s. Plots of land alongside the quay were sold off in 1751 and 1781 on which merchants rapidly built warehouses https://t.co/Ar845JaFCu
There has been a Regatta in Lancaster since 1842.  Rowing is thought of as a genteel sport so you would not expect it to be involved in such skulduggery as an electoral Royal Commission into bribery in 1865. All is revealed in our latest podcast  https://t.co/3UBPAqkuuA https://t.co/ElPOhRS9DZ
The first railway bridge over the River Lune lasted 20 years. 3 problems rose from the design: the threat of fire burning the timbers; water rotting the wooden beams; and the structure remaining stable when more, faster and ever-heavier trains crossed   https://t.co/ci0dp9KxxR
'A picturebook castle' is how the castle at Hornby has been described. Painted by the artist Turner, it became famous and was much visited. It was built by the Norman Montbegon family just after they arrived in Lancashire. It is still a private residence today. https://t.co/QUQXN4ARUj
In the late 18th and early 19th centuries there were masons, and stone quarries and coal pits in the hills to the south of the village. Small workshops made nails, swills (a kind of basket), clogs and bobbins for the cotton mills elsewhere.   https://t.co/aE1kjDf9ne
